review: 2.5?This book had a lot going for it that I would expect to love. Dragons! Romance! A main character who makes it through tough training on pure grit 2.5?This book had a lot going for it that I would expect to love. Dragons! Romance! A main character who makes it through tough training on pure grit alone! And there were certainly fun moments. Magical training academies will always appeal to me, and I liked how refreshing it was to have a fantasy military system where all genders are treated equally (and people can date whatever gender they want!). However, at the end of the day, I just couldn't get invested in Violet's story.To be clear, I am all for Not-That-Deep-But-Fun (NTDBF) reads. The Cruel Prince has very little substance and is filled with fairy balls, court intrigue, and a lot of tropes (most notably all the enemies to lovers "I hate them but I'm obsessed with them" stuff). I also have read hundreds of thousands of words of fanfiction, which is the very definition of an NTDBF read. But whereas I loved The Cruel Prince, and I devour fanfic, I just didn't have that much fun reading this book. I think the main thing that bothered me, aside from the plot feeling very predictable (and the Divergent parallels), was that I didn't care about any of the characters. Violet felt a little too perfect to me; something in her training progress was missing. She also had subtle "i'm not like other girls energy" with her silver hair and her [redacted-spoiler*]. I'd be curious to hear how disabled readers feel about the disability rep because, to me, it seems like it could have been expanded on and handled in a much more interesting way. When I don't like the main character of a book, it then makes it hard for me to get invested in the romance. I didn't buy the whole enemies part of Xaden and Violet's relationship since it was so clear he never actually hated her. And I am usually a fan of the forced proximity trope, but this book said "forced proximity every day all day for the REST OF YOUR LIFE" and that's kinda icky. In a world in which I cared about the characters, all my complaints about the romance would go away and i'd be like "yesssss forced proximity! yesss he was obsessed with her the whole time!! love love love"**. But I did not care, and so the questionable aspects of the story and relationships stood out to me instead. I'm glad that people had fun reading this book, and I'm thrilled if it got anyone back into reading. But, as someone who reads a lot of fantasy, I don't know if it merits all the hype it's getting.Also random, but if you loved the training and military academy aspect, consider reading the Protector the Small quartet by Tamora Pierce (starting with First Test). Sanderson mentions the Princess Bride as a reference, and I definitely see the similarities (win #1). I also saw a lot of Diana Wynne Jones' whimsy (win #2), Terry Pratchett's world-building (you know, the Discworld kind where the world is a little silly and absurd) (win #3), and both of these authors' witty and charming narratorial tones (win #4). Plus, Sanderson is a master at creating cool magic systems, and the spores in this book were no exception to this. (win #5). So many wins!! And that's just talking about the style and tone of the writing.As for the actual plot and characters, this is an Adventure book. It's a road trip (or sea trip) story, with a lot of pirates (!), a couple side quests, and an exciting final destination. Tress is so so smart, in a way that also feels very realistic, and I love her for it. I was also a big fan of the rest of the crew but I shan't say much on them to not spoil anything. Overall, it was just an excellent reading experience. Not once did I get stressed out while reading, because I could always trust that whatever happened next, it would be a fun time. review: 3.5 but notably rounded upWhat a dramatic ending to the series!!! My goodness. I read this book slowly at first, and then my friend Shayna started zoo3.5 but notably rounded upWhat a dramatic ending to the series!!! My goodness. I read this book slowly at first, and then my friend Shayna started zooming through the series so I simply had to speed up! Fortunately, my flight home provided the perfect wifi-less opportunity to do so. I really spent the whole 6-hour plane ride reading, and I went from 40% in, to the end of the book. Even though planes don't have wifi or cellular data, I still think this reading marathon is a testament to the captivating quality of this book. I could have watched a movie, but I just wanted to keep reading and find out what happened next!Overall it's a really strong conclusion to such a sweeping series, and the ending was appropriately dramatic and emotional. Mainly, the things I docked points on pertain to my own particular taste. For example, I am just not a huge fan of apocalypse narratives. They are so bleak. For most of this book, both the reader and the characters had to watch as the world crumbled away, without a single clue about how to save it, or destroy the force that was its cause. This made it hard for me to want to pick up the book since I just felt so directionless and hopeless. Of course, once the answers started to be hinted at, my investment came back, but that didn't change the doomedness of the overall ambiance. There was also a lot of world-explaining. This book took on the challenge of explaining  everything , from the plants, to allomancy, to the Lord Ruler, etc. Normally, I'm not a fan of my fantasy magic being explained. It dims the wonder and novelty of it, and it's often poorly done- the "logical" explanations end up creating more plot holes (see La Tempête Des Échos in the Mirror Visitor Series). However, I'm very impressed with Sanderson's world-explaining. He masterfully unraveled every single mystery of the series with both clarity and suspense. It's incredibly cool. The plot was less structured and none of the settinI've seen some degree of disappointment around this book, and I understand where it's coming from. The plot was less structured and none of the settings were as interesting as the Scholomance. Also, something that happens near the end is a little fudgy (especially going against the talks of Balance). That being said, I honestly just didn't care that much? I personally had a lot of fun reading this book, and I zoomed through it in 3 days. I have a lot of thoughts about it, so let's see how well I can wrap them up.One of my favorite parts of the series is El's narration style. There is A LOT of info dumping in this book (as I think there was in its predecessors), but I wasn't bothered by it because something in her narrative style makes it feel more like a conversation and less like a textbook (If that makes sense). (Wait I have a side ramble about the narration. One thing I found funny (? weird?) is that frequently El would come to these giant realizations in the middle of a really tense moment/conversation, but she'd make sure to talk through  this entire realization. So I'd be reading what felt like 3 pages of "Oh goodness if A then B, and C and oh! so this is who X is and what it all means" and the whole time my brain would be fascinated by the revelation but also like "EL! How do you have time to think all these thoughts! someone scary just asked you a question and is waiting for you to respond!!" The visual of El freezing to have these thoughts in the middle of a dangerous situation, was both hilarious and stressful. But maybe 3 pages of outlined thoughts equals 3 seconds of thinking time? I'm not sure why I noticed it so much in this book - I think in other books they do revelation->action->explanation-later, in that order. It just goes to show how readers' minds work and how there is so much situational context you hold at the back of your mind as you read through scenes.)Back to El herself. I understand that some people find her constant snarkiness grating, but I just love it. To me, she is the epitome of "kind, not nice" where she's just really mean to everyone while helping them, and it's hilarious. I also like that she is so (rightfully) angry at the carelessly privileged people around her, while simultaneously understanding that she can't blame them for wanting safe and comfortable lives for their families. On that note, I think there is a strong narrative around how people will do horrible exploitative things to protect themselves and their children and will continue to do so, so long as they see it as the easiest option (and they can ignore it). What impresses me though is that the book takes this cynically realistic view on humanity and spins it in a cautiously optimistic way: the idea that being good is a constant choice made again and again, but sometimes people will make that choice. El was definitely overpowered (and the balance argument does not really hold up IMO), however, I too sometimes wish some all-powerful being could freeze all the world and give everyone a good angry talking to, and shake some sense into us as a society. So I found it VERY satisfying when El could use her power to just yell at people. Overall, really enjoyed it. Wished there were more of all our favorite side characters (very little Orion, Aadhya, Liu etc.), but It was still a fun speedy read....more

I probably should have expected this from a story about a young man destined to become an evil dictator, but even so, I was unsettled. The mastery here is that Coriolanus's transition from a boy just trying to make it through the days, to a chillingly calculated young man was  so subtle . It's unnerving. You always want to be able to see a cause and effect in villain backstories, like "oh if that hadn't happened, then clearly he wouldn't have gone bad."Instead, hints of his extreme pride, ambition, entitlement, and fear* are peppered throughout the book. And when paired with a series of independent occurrences, these traits come together to reveal his nature in a way that makes sense in hindsight, but is nonetheless still shocking**That being said, this subtlety is the main strong point of the book. The first third is kind of tonally off - very poor-boy-in-prep-school vibes juxtaposed with post-war depression vibes juxtaposed with the Hunger Games. The middle third picks up speed but makes you feel morally confused (and sometimes horrified) in lots of ways, and last third is just more moral confusion in a different setting. The plot is pretty slow overall. I'd recommend it if you like psychological studies of how someone is driven to commit awful acts and justify them, or if you are hankering to know what the post-war Capitol was like (this also made me realize that 75 years for the capitol to be in complete power is actually not that long - kind of a fail for the Capitol lol). It's never outright discussed, but I believe that fear (of weakness, of powerlessness, of chaos) was a major driving force for Coriolanus, and a major justifier for his future actions, which I think is true of many dictators in real life. review: There's always going to be high emotional stakes when it comes to the final book in a series you really loved, and I knew that going in. Nevertheless,There's always going to be high emotional stakes when it comes to the final book in a series you really loved, and I knew that going in. Nevertheless, even that knowledge couldn't protect me from being very sad at the end. I have so many thoughts (and feelings!). First off, I definitely understand why people did not like this book as much (the lower average rating on Goodreads had mentally prepared me a little- though ofc it's still above 4 stars). In any instance where you build your world around fantasy, ancient libraries court intrigue, and all, it's going to feel like a huge shift when you set your last book in a mysterious medical facility with a clandestine purpose and strange protocols that mess up the patients' psyches. I myself was often creeped out. Additionally, this book seeks to answer every question that's come up in the series with very tangible metaphysical/sci-fi explanations. It was really fascinating to see how the author envisioned her world being created, (I have so much respect for her creativity), but there were frequent info dumps that left me more confused than I started. One twist, in particular, felt like it was added a little late for my taste. Plus, sometimes it's nice for fantasy to stay unexplained, y'know?And while the last third was indeed dramatic and action-filled, I'd hoped for more involvement from the cast of important side characters that had been slowly growing throughout the series.The ending also wrecked me a little. When you love a series so much, short, bittersweet/ambiguous epilogues are never going to cut it. *Cries forever* these characters deserve happiness.All that being said, I still found things to love about this book, and I don't think I would say the author let me down. Every single interaction between Ophélie and Thorn was truly beautifully written. Dabos wrote the transition from dislike, to respect, to fondness, to love between them in this series  so well , without sacrificing/changing any of the characters' true natures. And with characters so complex, that's not easy to do. And of course, there's the world. I've said this before, but Christelle Dabos' world-building is unparalleled. I have never read anything like this series. The blend of imagery between old fantasy (magic, illusions, nobles, balls), classic steampunk (dirigibles, telegrams, trains, mad inventors), and sci-fi (psych wards, robots, utopian metropolises with totalitarian governments) is a bold choice, but Dabos executes the balance perfectly, and create a mesmerizing world like no other. What I love about Lazlo, and this book, is that he was never willing to give up on a person and resort to violence. Despite everything he and the people he cares about have been through, he doesn't carry anger and bitterness, and instead fights so hard for peace (without making any rash love-based decisions!) Every side carries so much anger and guilt and self-hatred, which are very real emotions, for very real things that happen in life. It's hard to pinpoint a classic story arc in this book, and I know some would criticize it for this (including me at times), but ultimately, real life doesn't follow a story arc either, and so I can forgive this book for that. What it does give us is Character. And since the characters are arguably the best part of this series (although there is so much to love), this book absolutely shines. The interactions are incredible - every single one of them either hilarious, or ridiculously Dramatic, or painful, or terrifying (and sometimes all of those things once). review: SO MANY THOUGHTS.Ok this book totally captivated me. I read it all day on Sunday and until late at night, and in freaking Chem Lecture today (how do ySO MANY THOUGHTS.Ok this book totally captivated me. I read it all day on Sunday and until late at night, and in freaking Chem Lecture today (how do you find the most probable speed of a gas???IDK). And now I'm done, and I have so many thoughts: hmmmm.....First of all, everything is messy. The relationships between the various tribes is messy. Nahri and Ali's personal relationships are messy. The end is MESSY. And this is good and bad. It's good because it adds so much nuance to everything. For the reader, there is no comfortable side/tribe/person to root for. Everyone is flawed, every side has its horrible truths as well as its valid grievances. It really makes you look at everything from every single side. I would stop at saying the messiness was good, after all, it accurately represents the real, cutthroat dangerous world of court politics. However, as a reader it was exhausting! And the end is such a cliffhanger ugh. And so many secrets that are still hidden, so many miscommunications that have yet to be resolved. No me gusta. This is why I should only read standalones, or series that are already completed. Plot-wise, I was definitely not a fan of the desert road trip. I was mostly here for the court intrigue - which I luckily got a good dose of through Ali's chapters, and when Nahri finally gets herself to the city. Court intrigue, action-driven or not, turns out to be the thing that kept me reading so avidly this whole time (also waiting for Dara to be dumped, but I'll get to that later). Fair warning: there isn't a whole lot of action or even maybe plot, especially in the middle. I personally don't mind so much, but it could objectively be considered a flaw of the story. Let's talk characters:Nahri is a standard YA heroine. Spunky, and self-preserving, and independent and whatnot. I liked her as much as I like all the others, which is to say: fine. As I write this, I'm realizing that I wish we got to see more of her con/thief skills. They kind of just.... disappeared? Ali, on the other hand, fascinated me. I'm not sure I liked him better, he had so many problems with saying dumb things out of righteousness, and at times I wanted to roll my eyes, but it was that righteousness that made him so interesting. He's so conservative, so "this is the right thing, this is the wrong thing," black and white, but with such good intentions. I feel like this kind of exceedingly moral, religious, and uptight personality is not one I usually see in YA. Other s mention that Ali's faith was supposed to represent the Muslim faith, but I didn't read into that metaphor. He just seemed very religious, and I understand why people are upset that this book is advertised as having Muslim representation. Especially since every other character makes fun of his religiousness. Now Dara. Dara, Dara, Dara. I was predisposed against him from the moment we found out that he was both handsome, and 1500 years old. If there is one romantic trope I cannot stand, it is "young woman falls for old dude who looks young." It's CREEEPY. (cough cough Uprooted cough The Hero and the Crown cough). I complained to multiple people about it (who indulged me despite never having the intention of reading this book). It turns out my instinct was right. I predicted something would happen, and it did (no spoilers). He is such an Archer (from Fire). He's volatile, overprotective, arrogant, and, like, won't let go of his prejudices against shafit????? Basically I don't want to see him again, but I doubt I'll get that wish. Note: I get it, people in the real world are flawed, but why does everyone in this book have to have some form of intolerance or straight up racism? I want to scream at people at their blindness for the neverending hatred and animosity they cause. ( This ties back to my personal dislike of messiness, can you tell I'm an escapist reader yet?)In my typical fashion, I've gone and given mostly complaints about a book I mostly liked. I'm mainly just annoyed at the unresolved ending right now. It makes me uncomfortable. But if anything, it successfully shows how attached I am to this book and these characters, that I'm so bothered by this ending to a fictional story. We shall have to see what the next book has in store.P.S. The world building was pretty fantastic....more

This series still features all the great things I talk about below, but in the bigger picture, I'm able to see that all three books have slightly messy plots and somewhat funky pacing. It's also... just not that deep. BUT. depth is certainly NOT a requirement for FUN! and this series is still very fun. I love Jude and her beautiful messed-up faerie world, and while I wouldn't necessarily give any of the individual books 5 stars, the series as a WHOLE gets 5 stars for making me super excited while reading it even 5 years later. ---4.5 Reading this book while sick, I realized I was starting to drift further and further away from any care about the plot or characters. This is why I decided to put it down for a while and come back to the last 30 pages with a clear mind. So it is with a clear mind that I can say I REALLY enjoyed this book. It had basically everything I want from a book: multifaceted female characters, an interesting world, Court Intrigue (!), magic (!!), sword fights (!!!), fancy parties with fancy dresses and ballroom dancing(!!!!), and of course, a non-cringeworthy dash of romance.  The detailed world of faerie revels and enchanted forests reminded me of Wildwood Dancing, which is to say it was wonderfully beautiful and creepy at the same time. Jude, the main character, is admirably determined, and as we discover, rather ruthless. In fact, all the characters have a pretty significant dark side. This is no innocent fairytale, where the heroes escape bruised but with clean consciences. This is story about staying alive in a treacherous court, and that comes with moral sacrifice. Usually the fairytale books I read are more of the former type, and I was shocked to stumble upon such brutal actions in a fairyland, but by the end I thought it created some deeply interesting characters and motives. As for the plot, it goes in several directions. I never quite knew what was going to happen next, and the end certainly managed to surprise me! My one complaint is about a certain character who just… you think she’s cool and then she just turns out to be just plain…. annoying. She makes one decision and instantly loses so much credibility. It was frustrating and felt unrealistic. I’m not sure exactly how I originally found about this book, (I think Megan Whalen Turner read and recommended it) but I’ve been waiting for it for months. review: Every time I read this book, I'm more impressed with it. Kristin Cashore really said "I'm going to write a book about a nation recovering from collectEvery time I read this book, I'm more impressed with it. Kristin Cashore really said "I'm going to write a book about a nation recovering from collective trauma" and then went and did it. It's so unlike most YA fantasy out there and I can see how it's not everyone's cup of tea. For one, it's messy. There so many characters in the main cast and so many little mysteries that build up, that it's pretty hard to keep track of everything. And the story is also messy, not really following a classic plot in any way. But for me, that messiness is what makes it so realistic and so interesting.  How  do  societies rebuild after an era of oppression and trauma is suddenly concluded? How do people move forward, when nothing can bring back the loved ones they lost, and their search for the truth behind these losses is repressed by the new "better" government? It's so complicated, and I understand why many fantasy books skip over these issues, and yet it's clear Cashore did her research because these questions are relevant to real historical events. The other thing is that this book is  very  dark. A giant content warning for recurring mentions of rape, suicide, self-harm, torture, and domestic abuse. That being said, it never feels as though Kristin Cashore just drops these additions in for shock value. The whole motivation behind it is for Bitterblue to understand and cope with the trauma she and those around her have been through, and they actually address how upsetting it is for Bitterblue to discover these things. On the flip side, there is so much love and light in the story. I live for Katsa and Po's ridiculous antics, for the dialogue between our old friends Raffin, Bann, Giddon, and Helda. And I love Death and Madlen and Teddy and Saf, and everyone else who joins the circle of people that Bitterblue can trust throughout this book. It's a story about healing, of a nation, and of a young (superpower-less) girl who is just trying so hard to do right by her people. It's a beautiful conclusion to the trilogy (which isn't a trilogy anymore but I guess we'll see how I feel about Winterkeep). --Spoiler---(view spoiler)[ Ok literally how did I not remember how big of a character Giddon is in this story? I've realized that I'm just a sucker for books with themes of all-around love. Not just love between lovers, but also between friends, and real family, and found family. And also the kind that is complicated and makes no sense: the love people have for those that have hurt them, and those that have hurt others. The royal family in this book is so messy and torn up by awful events from the past, and yet they love each other so much, and their dynamics are wonderful to read. I'm also just a huge fan of good world-building, court intrigue, palaces, and balls so this really checks all the boxes for me :)Despite the fact that not much happens plot-wise in the first half, I really think it would make a great GOT-style TV show, with some added side plots (maybe intertwined with the Graceling story). The world and the characters are so well developed and the story is a good mix of gritty and beautiful (though definitely not as dark as GOT - which I think is a good thing). Anyways, I know it will never happen, but I like to dream about it. Interesting note: In the third book, Fire and the rest of the Dellians are described as dark-skinned and people, including myself, were skeptical of this sudden detail being added so late. However, after a close reading this time, it seems it might not have a late addition after all. The only times Fire describes people's skin color is to explicitly say that the Pikkians' pallor differentiates them from Dellians and that Leck is notably light-skinned - just as a book narrated by white people might only mention the color of people darker than them. Archer being blond, and the first edition cover of Fire certainly add to the confusion around this. review: Graceling is a phenomenal start to this series (one I adore). It sets a strong foundation for the complex themes that are explored in later books, allGraceling is a phenomenal start to this series (one I adore). It sets a strong foundation for the complex themes that are explored in later books, all the while following a relatively straightforward plot. It's fast-paced and exciting, but of course, where Cashore really shines is with her characters and relationships - also bonus points go to her absolutely terrifying(ly accurate) depiction of power abusers.There is so much Katsa hate in s (see later for a long description of why this makes me mad), but I love her and I think she really does read as an 18-year-old - albeit an incredibly powerful one. Her journey to finding agency in her life and reconciling who she wants to be with what she has done (a theme throughout all these books) feels real and important. And I love watching her relationships with Po and Bitterblue develop, as she learns the reaches of her power are ultimately limited by how much she can protect those she loves. I also just take a moment to shout out Kristin Cahsore's blog, where she shares her stories about making a literal library costume for Halloween ,  going to the arctic sea on a program for artists  (a trip I now know was for Winterkeep research!),  the reality behind in her fictional villains , and many other random things! Ok here's my moment to complain a bit (or a lot oops):On Goodreads, I've seen a large number of s that heavily criticize the portrayal of Katsa's attitude towards femininity and marriage. This book definitely does have flaws, and Kristin Cashore has written about of things she wishes she had done differently, but as for it this particular brand of criticism, I am tIrED of it.Katsa hates dresses, and swears that she will never marry. She doesn't want children, and she prefers to cut her hair short. "Wow what a feminist book! - look at all these gender norms being defied!!!!" the advertisers say, "Katsa is a modern hero! A true role model for young girls!" Incorrect! And many many people have already written long paragraphs about how going against gender norms does not inherently make a book feminist.  But here's where they go too far.  People act like Katsa's views on these things reflect a broader moral view of what girls should and shouldn't do. As if Katsa saying "I won't ever feel free if I marry" is supposed to imply a judgement on girls who  do  want to marry. First of all  nowhere  in the text does Katsa judge other women or their choices. She only know what her own experience is. And if you consider that this takes place in a high fantasy medieval world, she's not  that  out of touch with reality. Because yes, in that context, it doesn't matter how loving and fair and honest your husband is - at the end of the day, the law will judge that you are his property. So to apply her views to a modern context seems ridiculous. Second of all, even if we  did  judge her words in a modern context, it still wouldn't be #problematic. She's eighteen and entirely fictional, and grew up in traumatizing circumstances. Authors are not obligated to have their protagonists portray a perfect and nuanced worldview. Cashore was clearly not trying to tell young girls to never get married or wear pretty dresses (just look at the next two books)!In the end, Graceling is not a feminist book simply because the protagonist is a badass girl fighter who crushes the patriarchy. But it is a feminist book because it tells the story of one brave and flawed young woman, and gives her room to learn and grow from these flaws. Her perspective might be different than yours or mine, but that doesn't diminish the value of telling her story....more

review: 4.5Before reading this, I'd already watched Emma's story play out numerous times, whether it be through the Gwyneth Paltrow version, Clueless, or yout4.5Before reading this, I'd already watched Emma's story play out numerous times, whether it be through the Gwyneth Paltrow version, Clueless, or youtube's Emma Approved (made by the same people as, but far inferior to, Lizzie Bennet Diaries). And so I thought I knew exactly how I felt about this story and its characters. But of course, I was wrong, and I'm so happy I got to see this from a new light. There were some things that bothered me more so than in adaptations, the primary one being Mr. Knightley. I think he's great (far more of a real person than Darcy) and he and Emma's relationship development is still cute, but this book  kept on  emphasizing the age difference! Especially in the way he treats her as if he were a mentor. And he's a good dude, but he's literally always right in this book, and so the whole idea is that he's much wiser than her due to age. I would've liked to see more flaws, and I think some adaptations go about it slightly better. But the shining star of this book for me was Emma herself and how  so relatable  she is, particularly regarding: 1. Her long bouts of introspection where she sits down with herself after something has happened, and debriefs it all, and doesn't stop until she understands how she feels about it, and why. 2. Her rational approach to emotional subjects (like love and marriage) and how she doesn't understand how other people aren't similarly rational. 3. The mixture of both indignance and mortification she feels when being reprimanded for anything small or big. (Also she nearly calls out sexism a few times which is great)Emma is certainly very flawed: some of the time I felt called out, and some of the time I myself was frustrated with her. But overall, she is outwardly composed and put together in a way that doesn't quite transfer in film...Which brings me back to the adaptations, because I barely relate to Emma at all in them. And I think it's because so much of Emma's character is narrated from her mind, and her judgemental nature, while still mean in the book, appears even worse on screen, where she has to say everything she is thinking out loud for the viewers to understand. Due to her having to overtly talk badly of people, she is conveyed as more of a fake person than I believe her originally to be. Also Gwyneth and Romola, and Alicia, add a bit of caricature ridiculousness to her, which is very comedic and entertaining, but not quite how I picture her (Romola's version basically removes all dignity and composure, and exchanges it for a childish giddiness and eagerness that I thought was a bit much- but also pretty funny). ...more

The way Harry describes death as he comes to terms with facing it felt real and powerful, especially considering the close deaths that have just occurred.
